content.description:
Stem up the gully to a bushy ledge, then head right to the vertical crack. Climb to the alcove (optional belay) and then finish straight up with the crack.

This climb would grab another star if the brush bashing was eliminated.

Descent via rappel or off the east (climbers right) side via the path/scramble. NOTE: route is longer than 30 meters/100ft! Be careful on rappel!
content.protection: The gear is quite wide above the alcove.

content.description: The third bolted line from the left.  Start at the top of the loose gully.  5.9ish climbing past 3 bolts up to the horizontal break, then continue STRAIGHT past a steep, awkward bulge (crux).  There seems to be a trick here, but I'll let you figure it out for yourself.  Continue on easier ground to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Bolts, supplemental gear for upper section (optional).

content.description: Climb the gully as for Triple Overhang, but at the middle ledge, don't head quite as far right. Instead, take the crescent arch left and up to the spike under the roof.
content.protection: Mixed bolts and trad, anchors on top.

content.description:
Same start as

The Soul

.  At the horizontal break, cut right and up past bolts (avoiding the 11b crux of

The Soul

).  Well-protected face climbing leads to a 2-bolt anchor shared with

The Soul

.

climbs.name: Dazed and Confused
climbs.fa: B. Culver, J. Buhl, M. Brown, S. Edwards, 1993

content.description:
Dazed and Confused is the first bolted line encountered as you approach the crag from the Toxic Waste Wall (far left).  The route is the longest one on the wall, at around 120'.

Start just right of a gully, and stay on the vertical, crimpy face past 3 or 4 bolts for full value.  Bailing off left into the gully drops the difficulty down to 5.8.  Move up and left, passing a few more bolts, to gain a ledge.  Here's where a little gear comes in handy, as otherwise you'll have to make an unprotected couple of moves right before being able to clip the next bolt.  A fall here wouldn't be advised.  Use of a long sling off the ledge eases rope drag.  Steep, featured face climbing past a few more bolts to the top.

Be extremely careful lowering if using less than a 70m rope!
content.protection: Bolts, a couple TCUs, and at least one long sling.

content.description: From the lower level, take the right-most crack up to the horizontal break. Curve left and flow the arching crack up and left past the break.
content.protection: Trad. Last little bit is sporty, I believe. Bolts on top

content.description: Climb the obvious thin crack (5.8+, the crux of the route) that is just to the right of the starting bolts on A Route Runs Through It.  It is possible to place nuts and TCUs or to reach left and to clip bolts.  When you reach the break, climb the left-leaning crack through the bulge.  Once on the ledge atop the overhanging section, move 8 feet left and then follow the steep, crescent-shaped crack up and then right.  From the top of the crack head straight up clipping the last two bolts of A Route Runs Through It.
content.location:
Immediately right of the start of

A Route Runs Through It

.  See

topo

.

content.description: Perhaps the best line on the wall.  Start right of Dazed and Confused.  A tricky start leads to easier climbing past several bolts.  Pull through the steep roof (awesome!), and continue up vertical crimpfest and crux.
